comment.body: well, the point of ~99% coins & tokens is to get rich, so they need to "own" coin/token and convince others to buy it. and those who can't (technically or marketing-wise, or just lazy) issue their own tokens will buy someone else's in hope that it'd rise. so technically they don't even need real users to get rich, they only need to convince enough people to buy in
We are all zombies! Is Antarctica missing on purpose, btw?
@Kaffie: would reading "yes/no" answer to zombie-question actually help you getting closer to the truth?

Though i'm not even sure what meaning do you put into word zombie here. Because good old p-zombies are undetectable by design. And if you have a specific zombie definition like "whoever doesn't remember the real past = zombie", you probably don't have to ask directly; but using word "zombie" would be misleading for that definition, i think.

@Kaffie: "p-zombie [..] is a hypothetical being that from the **outside** is **indistinguishable** from a normal human [..]" (wikipeida); if you agree to this definition, there is no way to estimate whether they exist or not. Otherwise, please give (link) your definition.

@Kaffie: ok, thx for clarification. My opinion on "p-zombie argument" per se is that it's not very useful because it only works for those who already kinda agree with it (and true physicalist should reject it). As for your definition of zombies, well, i also used to think that anybody who can't understand concept of "consciousness" ("ÑÐ¾Ð·Ð½Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ" to be more precise; in my understanding "qualia" are parts of it) in the way i used it, lacks it. But at some point i seemed to be able to explain it and given how hard it was, i can no longer be sure that someone who *doesn't* seem to understand it, necessarily *can't* understand it (and thus lacks consciousness). I think most people simply never bother with introspection and are too attached to materialism to understand it.
And, to answer your question: no, i don't perceive myself as zombie; i do perceive consciousness and qualia.
@Kaffie: hmm, apparently you made a capitalization mistake. file is called `JCP.png`, but you reference it as `jcp.png`
@Kaffie: file is not found because its name is misspelled, so it would hash empty string or something like that
@Kaffie: perhaps you're using case-insensitive fs&/os; it is the same as in picture now
Well, apparently not everybody reads [xkcd classics](https://xkcd.com/927/)
Hmm, it certainly has confusing name. But brief description seems to be quite clear about what it does..

@Krixano: yeah, i agree it's a little more useless than one might think from its name. But both description of firefox addon and especially one on eff page imply that it simply uses whitelist to prevent accidental http on sites with https: "on sites that are known to support it" (ff) and "with many major websites" (eff page).
It still has usecases, though. There are many old links that nobody is going to fix. I'm not exactly sure what happens during http redirection to https (i.e. whether it leaks url or not), but i suppose the addon was created back when it wasn't widespread anyway

I think the core reason is that strong emotions affect reasoning. This leads to the fact that many people exploit others' emotions and manipulate them. Thus, in a *trustless* community genuine emotions are widely seen as weakness. Another related thing is that emotions can be transmitted via empathy and thus fake emotions can also be used to attempt manipulation (that's one of the basics of arts).

This of course shouldn't be enough to actually *stigmatize* emotions for rational people, just be careful about them. But people tend to choose extremes. "Stigma" sounds like a strong word and if i read it correctly, only emotional people would actually go as far as to stigmatize emotions.

@Krixano: my familiarity with usa culture is only tangential. But i may speculate the current emotion situation there isn't fundamentally different from the long standing debate on "human nature". Conservative thought (and i don't mean any specific parties or movements here) generally considers humans as dangerous. And the most dangerous thing in them is of course uncontrolled "negative emotions", because instrumental reason is supposed to be negotiable, even with an opponent.
The current usa anti-emotion "lobby" may have roots in freudism, reaction to nazism and then reaction to hippie and possibly other related 1960s movements (which, despite being "based" on "positive emotions" still looked like existential threat to governmental system).
Interestingly enough, many "progressivists" share the same conservative approach and despite claiming to trust people to be good, do not act on it and like to suppress emotions in their own way (or even in the same way).

I suppose it's the basis of virtually any large society: to frame emotions, limit their expression to ritualized or otherwise safe venting. I don't want to speculate whether it's actually necessary or not, just trying to analyze existing and historical situation. And of course, amount of repression might differ.

As for public online situations, since there's usually also little trust between peers, the same conservative approach is often being used. Showing emotions is considered to be sign of weakness (cult of strength is another large topic, i suppose) and empathizing to someone's emotions seen as danger to be manipulated either into acting irrational or just plain feeling bad.

It is quite sad (though understandable) to see that meat-eaters vs vegan/vegetarian debates still continue on this level. I have no idea how good soylent actually is and frankly that *doesn't even matter*. We live in a scientific age and should accept already that the same chemical (including organic) matter can be created in different ways. And if *some* vegans&vegetarians don't have a balanced diet, that has nothing to do with idea, because surely most meat eaters also have bad diets, simply because most humans don't care enough about their health to do proper research and then follow it.

>Intermittent

For my non-native ear this sounds like a rare and not very poetic word. "Odd" might create a better rhythm, but it is also adds a lot of (perhaps) unrelated meaning.

>Sound sleep did not dispel the slight drunk.

If "drunk" here refers to "state of being drunk", it might be not very obvious. If it refers to "drunk person", i've no idea what should that mean.

Nah, most "smartphones" have removable external batteries (sold separately, though). That thing inside is mainly for the clock and also to make sure you can switch external batteries without rebooting.

>PEP 572

Hmm, so instead of writing "however, assignment cannot be used as expression because that would be confusing to new users" python tutorials would now have to write "however, you'll have to be careful when to use ':' in your assignments and whether to use parentheses or not (because we'd like to not type ':' whenever possible, still have assignment expressions and not confuse assignment with comparison)". Great. A big achievement in language design intended to be understandable, indeed.
If you want to go even deeper, there's dependent types and the whole world where constructive math and programming are isomorphic ("types as propositions", "programs as proofs").

@leftside: b is not declared "inside" function, it's parameter, whose default value is created at the moment of creating function. Why is that the case? If i have to guess, because if you write something like `def foo(a=bar)`, it will be always bound to one bar. So why should it behave differently when you use "proper" expression vs empty list constructor? It would be possible to wrap all expressions into a function, but that is extra work and reproducing current behaviour with such design would be harder than reproducing other behaviour with current one

@klu9@zeroid.bit: not sure if it could cause any problems, but you really shouldn't be using `\` slash on web. Also if you want something gif-like, but not gif, there are animated png and webp formats

> "Tor: error"

> Port: Opened

Unless you set "tor: always" mode, tor is optional, so 0net will work without it (though lacking ability to connect to tor-only nodes), but unless you disable it completely (?) 0net will still check whether it's available and thus you get error report if it's not found (in expected way)

> help support other ZeroNet developers by donating to their public address with Bitcoin

I think this was pointed out before, but that's likely a [very bad idea](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Address_reuse#Security), probably even more dangerous than usual address reuse as we're signing much more messages than regular transactions
Well, why should everybody be permitted to take part in enslaving people? It's a tough market!

Personally, i don't have much expectations about that kind (or any, really) parties. If you're bored, try to inspect people. Sometimes, that might be fun.

And don't be too afraid of interacting with others: even if they consider you "outsider", they might be interested in you, because chances are, they are bored of their inner circle; you're unlikely to lose something, unless you're living in a very aggressive and discontent society (Well, if you are, maybe it would be better to spend effort to change location than try to go to a party).

Another thing: if you go to parties or other social interaction not expecting anything particularly exciting, you are more likely to be surprised in a good way. If you're actively looking to be social, random parties might not be the best option.
I'm not a expert, but if possible, i would try to dd it into a file and then try to work with that.

Depends on your goal and current knowledge. But generally i'd say: don't learn languages, learn ideas and concepts. Well, at some point you may need to learn language specifics, but if you understand ideas behind it, it isn't that hard. Functional programming, lambda calculus, high-order typing systems, some relevant bits of category theory. Might sound scary, but it can be argued this is easier path than the usual imperative/object-oriented hell.

If you insist on learning a language, i probably have to recommend Haskell, because i'm not sure Agda, Idris or other dependently typed language would have enough beginner-friendly docs.

If you insist on your list, python>js>php. Why even bother with php in 2019 unless you specifically plan to participate in a project that uses it?
I'm pretty sure this was linked somewhere around here ;)
@klu9@zeroid.bit: [here](?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/1PSaHi14Xh4Kjo3yyjDgbRtj4YLQgWV4QJ/1542119726) it is

@Pexo: yeah, i also think that deniability high quality fakes create might be used for good. However, the problem is that if we can't trust anything, we can't make educated choice about lots of things. Another problem is that most people would never choose to believe nothing: rather, they would keep their existing beliefs and dismiss anything else as fakes. Wait, that's already happening now.. whatever

@Pexo: 

> But that implies that they already had this particular believe about you

I wasn't talking about beliefs about individuals, but about more global things. Most people have some beliefs about politics, science and many are ok with current low quality fakes to keep believing in otherwise "obviously wrong" things. Higher quality widespread fakes can for many people provide both further support of their beliefs as well as guard against changing it, because anything can be dismissed as fake.

> the point is to stop his(or her) belief from spreading

My point is that they are already wide spread. Nobody enters the future world of total fakes with clean state, virtually everyone (even children) would have some point of reference which they trust (almost) unconditionally. They will have little incentive to doubt their views, because if everything equally fakeable, the easiest thing to do is to stick to whatever you have.

If they wanted to analyze sms, what would stop them from uploading them to server before you delete them? I think simplest explanation would be that they have rewritten app from scratch and simply did not implement such functionality (rather than removed it on purpose). Might sound weird to not implement something basic like that, but then again it seems to be a custom among interface designers to cut every feature they can get away with. And also to consider users idiots, which brings us to another version: maybe someone have suffered from this function and had enough weight to push its removal

While it may be annoying, the point might be exactly to force learners to get acquainted with "=" form because it is more natural for *functions*; and letting experience learners to go with block form will allow them to skip this syntax altogether.

Not saying it's necessarily good decision, but then so isn't making or teaching Kotlin in the first place in my opinion

@Pexo: most people manage to find big enough circle with the same beliefs, now or then. They will happily keep sharing their "knowledge" among themselves and occasionally try to bring outsiders (which would do roughly the same), but most likely will be met with "no, your fake" and there is no reasonable continuation of this argument if all the factual side (beside maybe actual eyewitnessing) can be faked. So people who don't like arguments will simply continue with their opinion and those who do will participate in endless holywars.

Essentially, for all we know *everything* around us might be fake, but most people dismiss that idea and even those who don't usually continue with the lives as if they aren't fake.

> you need to prove your point as best as you can to convince anybody.

Most people who have uneducated, unethical or plain silly views that i've argued with, do not even try. Exactly because they are used to their circle where they don't need to try hard to be convincing. There is no need to prove as best as you can, because there will be enough of people who will agree with you nevertheless.

@klu9@zeroid.bit:

> it shows up in my ZeroHello feed as a published post

0hello shows everything that went into your local database, which afair doesn't even require signing, just changing related .json is enough.

> Any suggestions appreciated.

Most likely just not enough peers at the moment of publication. Maybe try again?

If that doesn't help: is update timestamp (can be seen on 0hello near site) current or still shows yesterday? Did you get "content signed, but no peers found message"? Did you see console output / logs?

@klu9@zeroid.bit: oh, sorry, i didn't mean browser console, i meant output of zeronet (if you don't run zeronet from command line, you won't get it "in console" (maybe it's duplicated in logs, not sure))

So, trying again didn't help? (i mean open 0-menu in top-right corner and press "sign & publish content, not creating new post or something)

Also, added (visited) it on 0net.io proxy. That's +1 node that may help

The logs should be located in zeronet directory `/log`
@klu9@zeroid.bit: it does work for me now ;)

@klu9@zeroid.bit:

> the proxy may not be up-to-date or doesn't include my zite

Public proxies tend to allow adding new sites. If one proxy is not updated, check another one?..

Also, if in doubt, throwing another "sign and publish" should show whether you can push content at least to some peers. Now with optional content it's a little bit harder: unless you access it with proxy, there is little way to know for sure whether someone else will be able to download it at any given time (especially if you use tor-only mode or no tor and port closed; or if you don't have your node up all time). Though if you have an open port + tor node that runs 24/7, optional content shouldn't be a problem

Essentially KaffieId (and others like it, though it seems they've lost popularity) simply circumvents the system which was intended for spam protection (and pretty names, i guess). We could just as well use public keys directly.
  
And i think in the end, that's what is going to be best. Just using public keys, allow users to set arbitrary pretty names and have a more robust spam-protection based on peers exchanging white/black lists

@Caropc6: i'm not sure last part of my post was translated quite correctly (i tried to run translation back, lol; so it might be issue on either pass); it should rather read "use public keys **and** allow users to set arbitrary names **and** have a more robust spam-protection based on peers exchanging white/black lists", but one does not directly follow from the other (like "Using only public keys, it allows users to define arbitrary beautiful names and have more robust peer-based spam protection that exchange white / black lists." suggests). Hopefully this post make any sense in translation ;)

from the article itself (not its misleading title) :

> Additional precise and specific actions must also be taken:

> Reveal who is paying for advertisements, how much they are paying and who is being targeted.

> Commit to meaningful transparency of platform algorithms so we know how and what content is being amplified, to whom, and the associated impact.

> Turn on by default the tools to amplify factual voices over disinformation.

> Work with independent researchers to facilitate in-depth studies of the platformsâ€™ impact on people and our societies, and what we can do to improve things.

the only thing which can be stretched as "censorship" is "tools to amplify factual voices" , but however one is interpreting it , tools amplifying one kinds of sources over others *already exist* ; tweaking them from favouring altright to favouring antialtright doesn't make it any more or less censorship

granted , i don't know what's in the video (clearly the worst format to have substantial discussion rather than propaganda ; i'm willing to discuss its content if textual version with proofs is present) , but the composition of speculation and unrelated direct source (seemingly as a proof) is a good sign of manipulation

compiler translates into higher-level lang than it's written in, huh. still, nice size!

it's easy to see people making a bad argument , though . it's fine to make highly controversial statements , but if you want it to be taken seriously by anyone who isn't already onboard , you have to give proofs (references) for those
